metadata.title: Species delimitation and DNA barcoding for Chinese Mantodea (Insecta, Dictyoptera)
metadata.description: DNA barcoding has been proposed as a rapid and reliable tool for animal identification and species delineation. The 5' end of the mitochondrial cytochrome c oxidase I gene (COI-5P) was sequenced for 318 specimens of 55 mantis species. Of these, 44 species had not been sequenced before, thus being new COI-5P barcode sequences to science. Another 61 COI-5P barcode sequences comprising five species were retrieved from the Barcode of Life Database (BOLD; www.boldsystems.org). Five species delimitation algorithms were employed to sort barcode sequences into Molecular Operational Taxonomic Units (MOTUs), namely the distance-based Barcode Index Number (BIN) System, Generalized Mixed Yule Coalescent (GMYC), a Java program that uses an explicit, determinate algorithm to define Molecular Operational Taxonomic Unit (jMOTU), Assemble Species by Automatic Partitioning (ASAP), and Bayesian implementation of the Poisson Tree Processes model (bPTP). All species, except Hierodula chinensis Werner, 1929, were recovered as monophyletic on the neighbor-joining (NJ) tree. For the final dataset, 379 COI-5P barcode sequences were assigned to 68 BINs. Fifty-five out of 68 BINs obtained were new to BOLD. The low level of BIN overlap with other nations highlights the importance of constructing a regional DNA barcode reference library. The algorithms ASAP, jMOTU, bPTP, and GMYC clustered barcode sequences into 32, 58, 68, and 60 MOTUs, respectively. All species delimitation algorithms (except ASAP analysis) split Anaxarcha sinensis Beier, 1933, Anaxarcha zhengi Ren & Wang, 1994, H. chinensis, Spilomantis occipitalis (Westwood, 1889), Titanodula formosana Giglio-Tos, 1912 into more than one MOTUs. All algorithms merged Hierodula sp. BCM-2019 and H. chinensis into the same MOTU, as for Tenodera aridifolia Stoll, 1813 and Tenodera sinensis Saussure, 1871. More accurate identification results need to be supplemented by detailed morphological classification.
references: Ahmadzadeh F, Flecks M, Carretero MA, Mozaffari O, Bӧhme W, Harris DJ, Freitas S, Rӧdder D (2013) Cryptic speciation patterns in Iranian rock lizards uncovered by integrative taxonomy. PLoS ONE 8(12): e80563. https://doi.org/10.1371/journal.pone.0080563

metadata.title: Garsauria aradoides Walker
metadata.description:
Garsauria aradoides Walker

Garsauria aradoides Walker, 1868: 536.

Material examined: BRUNEI, Pulau Selirong FR, 4°52’57.42’’N 115°8’13.80’’E, Mangrove forest, bridge over creek, MVP light, no rain, 22.VII.2014, 6 pm - 4 am, leg. C. Damken, 1 ex.

Distribution (Lis J. A. 1992, 1993, 1994, 1999): Moluccas, Papua New Guinea, Solomon Islands, Indonesia (Java, Sumatra, Buru, Ambon, Irian Jaya), Malaysia (Sarawak). New to Brunei.

Voucher data: UO sample number: UO_217Ga; GenBank accession number: OR691647.

locations.description: Material examined: BRUNEI, Pulau Selirong FR, 4°52'57.42''N 115°8'13.80''E, Mangrove forest, bridge over creek, MVP light, no rain, 22.VII.2014, 6 pm - 4 am, leg. C. Damken, 1 ex.

references: Walker F. 1868. Catalogue of the specimens of Hemiptera Heteroptera in the collection of the British Museum 3: 418 - 599. British Museum (Natural History), London.

journal.title: New distributional data for nine interesting Old World burrower bug species (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Cydnidae), pp. 173-175 in Heteroptera Poloniae - Acta Faunistica

metadata.notes: Published as part of Lis, Jerzy A. & Domagała, Paweł J., 2023, New distributional data for nine interesting Old World burrower bug species (Hemiptera: Heteroptera: Cydnidae), pp. 173-175 in Heteroptera Poloniae - Acta Faunistica 26 (1) on page 173, DOI: 10.5281/zenodo.10428055

metadata.title: Code Architectures for Android Applications: A Comprehensive Study
metadata.description: The development of Android applications requires a solid foundation of code architecture to ensure maintainability, scalability, and effective user experience. This study explores the various code architecture patterns commonly used in Android development, including Model-View-Controller (MVC), Model-View-Presenter (MVP), Model-View-ViewModel (MVVM), and Clean Architecture. It highlights the advantages and limitations of each pattern and provides insights into how modern Android development practices, such as Jetpack libraries and dependency injection, integrate into these architectures. Furthermore, the paper discusses real-world examples and best practices for implementing these patterns to achieve optimal results in Android application development.

journal.title: INTERNATIONAL JOURNAL OF INNOVATIVE RESEARCH AND CREATIVE TECHNOLOGY

data.title: Code Architectures for Android Applications: A Comprehensive Study

metadata.title: Agile Project Management - Less Planning, More Doing
metadata.description:
Agile Project Management focuses on adaptability, efficiency, and achieving high-impact outcomes. The core principles include:

  1. Goal Orientation & Focus

    • Identify clear objectives and find the shortest path to achieving them.
    • Prioritize execution over excessive planning.
    • Minimize unnecessary involvement and focus on problem resolution.

  2. Simplicity & Efficiency

    • Keep documentation minimal and relevant.
    • Use small, self-organizing teams with reduced dependencies.
    • Leverage innovative tools and techniques to optimize productivity.

  3. Synergies & Sociability

    • Identify interconnections between projects to maximize efficiency.
    • Foster a collaborative and constructive environment, assuming goodwill.

  4. Impact & Self-Criticism

    • Choose paths that yield the highest return on effort.
    • Reflect on execution to refine processes and maximize effectiveness.

  5. Realistic Planning & Adaptability

    • Avoid overcomplicating project scopes; focus on MVP (Minimum Viable Product).
    • Balance prioritization by evaluating realistic constraints.
    • Encourage an open culture of critical assessment and learning from failures.

data.title: Agile Project Management - Less Planning, More Doing

metadata.title: Digitally-Enhanced Laboratory Operations: Transforming Innovation through LIMS for Efficiency and Scalability
metadata.description: This paper examines the critical aspects of implementing a Laboratory Information Management System (LIMS) to support key functions within laboratories as part of a Minimum Viable Product (MVP). The study explores essential LIMS functionalities, including sample lifecycle management, request processing through portals, instrument interfacing, and batch management. It also delves into challenges and opportunities related to master data management, out-of-the-box (OOB) stability, and intellectual property (IP) management. From the Business Analyst (BA) and Quality Assurance (QA) Lead perspectives, this paper highlights the methodologies, strategies, and frameworks necessary for successfully deploying LIMS solutions. It emphasizes aligning stakeholder requirements, addressing technical complexities, and ensuring robust quality standards to enhance laboratory efficiency and compliance.

journal.title: International Journal of Leading Research Publication

data.title: Digitally-Enhanced Laboratory Operations: Transforming Innovation through LIMS for Efficiency and Scalability

metadata.title: Fig. 5 in First evidence of cryptic diversity in mud dragons (kinorhyncha) and description of Echinoderes quasae sp. nov. from the northeastern pacific coast
metadata.description: Fig. 5. Light (DIC) micrographs showing details of Echinoderes quasae sp. nov. Male holotype NHMD-1785640 (A-D, G, H), female hologenophore NHMD-1785649 (F). A, Overview, ventral. B, Neck and segments 1–2, ventral view. C, Neck and segments 1–2, dorsal view. D, segments 6–9, ventral view. E, segments 4–9, dorsal view. F, female segments 10–11, dorsal view. G, male segments 10–11, dorsal view. H, male, segments 10–11, ventral view. Abbreviations: ldgco2, laterodorsal glandular cell outlet type 2; ldss, laterodorsal sensory spot; ltas, lateral terminal accessory spine; lts, lateral terminal spine; lvs, lateroventral spine; mdgco1, middorsal glandular cell outlet type 1; mds, middorsal spine; mlgco2, midlateral glandular cell outlet type 2; mvp, midventral placid; pdss, paradorsal sensory spot; pe1/3, penile spines 1–3; sdgco2, subdorsal glandular cell outlet type 2; sdss, subdorsal sensory spot; si, sieve plate; slgco1/2, sublateral glandular cell outlet type 1/ 2; tp, trichoscalid plate; vlgco2, ventrolateral glandular cell outlet type 2; vmgco1, ventromedial glandular cell outlet type 1; vmss, ventromedial sensory spot; te, tergal extension. Arrow marks the midventral division on segment 2. Arrowhead marks the middorsal division on segment 11. Circles indicate the position of glandular cell outlets type 1. Dashed circles indicate the position of sensory spots. Digits after abbreviations refer to segment number.
metadata.notes: Published as part of Herranz, María, Leander, Brian S. & Grzelak, Katarzyna, 2024, First evidence of cryptic diversity in mud dragons (kinorhyncha) and description of Echinoderes quasae sp. nov. from the northeastern pacific coast, pp. 241-254 in Zoologischer Anzeiger 313 on page 247, DOI: 10.1016/j.jcz.2024.10.010, http://zenodo.org/record/14701480

metadata.title: Fig. 10 in Sphenoderes japonicus sp. nov. - The first deep water representative of the family Semnoderidae (Kinorhyncha, Cyclorhagida) in the sea of Japan
metadata.description: Fig. 10. Scanning electron micrograph of Sphenoderes japonicus sp. nov., adult male. A, first trunk segment, frontal view. B, trunk segments 1–4, ventrolateral view from right side. C, trunk segments 1–9, dorsolateral view from right side. D, trunk segments 5–8, dorsolateral view from left side. Bar A-B, 10 μm; C, 50 μm; D, 20 μm. Abbreviations: ff, free flap; lvac, lateroventral acicular spine; mdac, middorsal acicular spine; mdp, middorsal placid; mva, midventral cuticular apron; mvp, midventral plscid; sf, secondary fringe; number after abbreviation indicates corresponding segment; white continuous circles indicates sensory spots.
metadata.notes: Published as part of Adrianov, A.V. & Maiorova, A.S., 2024, Sphenoderes japonicus sp. nov. - The first deep water representative of the family Semnoderidae (Kinorhyncha, Cyclorhagida) in the sea of Japan, pp. 161-174 in Zoologischer Anzeiger 313 on page 171, DOI: 10.1016/j.jcz.2024.10.003, http://zenodo.org/record/14701192

metadata.title: Fig. 7 in Sphenoderes japonicus sp. nov. - The first deep water representative of the family Semnoderidae (Kinorhyncha, Cyclorhagida) in the sea of Japan
metadata.description: Fig. 7. Light micrographs of Sphenoderes japonicus sp. nov., young female (MIMB49935). A, C, F, G, dorsal view. B, E, ventral view. A-D, total view; C, neck and trunk segments 1–6; D, trunk segments 9–11; E, neck and trunk segments 1–5; F, trunk segments 10–11; G, trunk segment 11. Bar A-B, 100 μm; C-G, 50 μm. Abbreviations: ldac, laterodorsal acicular spine; lva, lateroventral articulation; lvac, lateroventral acicular spine; lvs, lateroventral additional spine; mdac, middorsal acicular spine; mva, midventral articulation; mvp, midventral placid; number after abbreviation indicates corresponding segment; white dotted arrow indicates sensory spot type 3; black arrowhead indicates anterior border of first trunk segment; black pecked arrow indicates paraventral fissures of first trunk segment.
